results.title: Europe fails to take the shine off Tiffany profits
results.content:
Europe was the only sour note in the latest quarter for Tiffany & Co as the high-end jeweller reported a jump in earnings and lifted its profit forecast for the year.

Sales growth in China, Japan, Australia and the US catapulted the New York-based retailer's revenues up 13 per cent to $1bn in the quarter to April 30 from $895m in the year ago quarter.

Same-store sales - a key metric for retailers climbed 11 per cent, comfortably topping Wall Street's forecast of 4.8 per cent.

Best known for its flagship store on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue, Tiffany's ability to tap wealthier customers has allowed it to avoid the struggles many retailers have faced since the financial crisis.

Michael J. Kowalski, the chief executive, said:

We were pleased with the strong and broad-based sales growth across most regions

Here'a a breakdown of its same-store sales in the quarter:

  • Americas: 8 per cent

  • Japan: 30 per cent

  • Europe: (-) 3 per cent

  • Asia-Pacific: 10 per cent

That led to overall profits for the quarter of $126m, or 97 cents a share, up from $84m, or 65 cents, a year earlier.

The performance prompted Tiffany to lift its full-year earnings forecast to a range of $4.15 a share to $4.25 a share, up from $4.05 a share to $4.15 a share.

Tiffany shares rose 4 per cent in pre-market trading. They've gained 12.6 per cent in the last 12 months.
results.abstract: Europe was the only sour note in the latest quarter for Tiffany & Co as the high-end jeweller reported a jump in earnings and lifted its profit forecast for the year.

results.title: Treasury rally buoys mortgage refinancing - MBA
results.content:
US mortgage applications climbed last week, but it wasn't to do with the much-heralded spring-selling season.

An index of applications climbed 0.9 per cent last week, the Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) said on Wednesday.

The jump was driven by an increase in demand from Americans wanting to refinance existing mortgages, rather than take out fresh mortgages to buy homes.

A refinance index rose 4 per cent in the week to May 16 from the prior week, while an index of mortgage applications for new purchases fell 3 per cent.

Mike Fratantoni, chief economist at the MBA, put the the increased appetite for refinancings down to mortgage rates that had been dragged lower by falling yields on US government bonds.

Although average house prices are still clocking double-digit annual growth in the US, housing market activity - sales, mortgage applications and construction of new homes - have all stalled.

The Federal Reserve went public with its concern last week that activity may not pick up.
results.abstract: US mortgage applications climbed last week, but it wasn't to do with the much-heralded spring-selling season.

results.title: China and Russia sign landmark gas deal
results.content:
China and Russia signed an 11th hour agreement to import natural gas from Russia's Gazprom during a state visit by President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday following strenuous Russian efforts to secure what has been portrayed as a key test of closer Sino-Russian ties.

As Moscow's relations with the West have deteriorated over the crisis in Ukraine, Mr Putin has sought to show the world and the Russian people that he has alternative friends to the east, reports Lucy Hornby and Jamil Anderlini.

While Europe is addicted to Russian gas, Moscow is equally dependent on European clients for revenues, and the deal with China will reduce that significantly.

The agreement between Russa's state-controled Gazprom and China National Petroleum Corporation will open up for the development of Siberian fields and the supply of 38bn cubic metes og natural gas annually over 30 years, starting in 2018.

That is equal to about 23 per cent of current Chinese consumption and 16 per cent of Gazprom's exports. CNPC did not give details on the pricing of the gas, the sticking point in negotiations that have stretched over a decade.
results.abstract: China and Russia signed an 11th hour agreement to import natural gas from Russia's Gazprom during a state visit by President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday following strenuous Russian efforts to secure what has been portrayed as a key test of closer Sino-Russian ties.

results.title: Ireland's DCC flies the conglomerate flag
results.content:
Let's hear it for the conglomerate.

Ireland-based DCC Group, with interests ranging from energy to healthcare to technology, unveiled an 11.5 per cent rise in operating profit on Wednesday for the year to March 31, beating forecasts and pushing the shares up 5.1 per cent, reports Vincent Boland

DCC generates around 90 per cent of its revenue - which reached over £11bn in the year to March - from energy distribution (including petrol stations), healthcare (making things such skincare creams) and technology distribution.

Revenue growth was especially strong in tech (up 16 per cent) and healthcare (up nearly 40 per cent). But DCC's stand-out characteristic is its return on capital employed, the benchmark that Tommy Breen, chief executive, says is the company's most important.

Given that its cost of capital is "in the mid single digits", he says, DCC's return on capital employed of just over 16 per cent in the year to March looks impressive. This is a continuation of a trend in place almost since DCC became a listed company 20 years ago, and is driven by profit growth and capital management.

That profit growth is in turn driven by acquisitions. DCC makes frequent bolt-on acquisitions to add to its core divisions. Already this year it has bought a healthcare business in the UK for an enterprise value of £13m, and a petrol distribution company in Sweden for £40m.

DCC has plenty of ammunition to maintain that strategy and perhaps do bigger acquisitions, given that it has almost no debt and generated free cash flow of £225m in the year to March. Given its position in the energy distribution market, investors should probably expect more on that front.

"Given what is going on in the energy markets, the pace of divestment is likely to quicken. That is a sweet spot for us," Mr Breen tells the FT.
results.abstract:
Let's hear it for the conglomerate.

Ireland-based DCC Group, with interests ranging from energy to healthcare to technology, unveiled an 11.5 per cent rise in operating profit on Wednesday for the year to March 31, beating forecasts and pushing the shares up 5.1 per cent, reports Vincent Boland

results.title: Fast New York Open: Flies on the wall
results.content:
It's the day investors get to be a fly on the wall during the deliberations of Federal Reserve policymakers - albeit with a three week lag.

The release of the minutes of the April 29-30 meeting of the Fed's Open Monetary Committee should be the main event of the day for equity and bond markets trying to discern the central bank's next step.

fastFT will have a fuller preview shortly, but the minutes are released at 2pm New York time.

Otherwise the economic calendar is bare with the exception of the latest weekly reading of mortgage applications.

With US stocks close to record highs and the Treasury market proving resilient, the ultimate focus remains on whether the US economy can accelerate quickly enough to prompt the Fed to raise interest rates for the first time since the financial crisis.

For now, Yellen and her allies on the FOMC, including New York Fed president Bill Dudley, have signalled that growth has not reached that pace.

Equity investors will also be paying close attention to the final blast of first-quarter US earnings, with retailers now dominating. Target, a rival to Walmart, and high-end jeweller's Tiffany's both report today.
results.abstract: It's the day investors get to be a fly on the wall during the deliberations of Federal Reserve policymakers - albeit with a three week lag.

results.title: Lowe's still enjoying US housing market's ride
results.content:
Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen has concerns about the US housing market, but America's largest DIY chains are still enjoying the ride the market's recovery is providing.

A day after its rival Home Depot reported higher profits for the last quarter, Lowe's has done the same.

Despite a harsh winter on the east coast of the US, the chain's same-store sales climbed 0.9 per cent - beating expectations of 0.5 per cent.

In another echo of Home Depot, Lowe's said that business has picked up as winter retreats and the spring selling season unfolds.

Robert A. Niblock, the chief executive of Lowe's, said:

Performance has improved in May which, together with our strengthening execution, gives us the confidence to reaffirm our sales and operating profit outlook for the year.

For the three months to May 2, sales climbed to $13.4bn from $13.1bn. In turn, profits jumped to $624m from $540m.
results.abstract: Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen has concerns about the US housing market, but America's largest DIY chains are still enjoying the ride the market's recovery is providing.

results.title: BoE "more balanced" on rate hike: reaction
results.content:
Here's a quick round-up of reaction to Wednesday's revelation that some members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee believe the decision on whether to lift interest rates off their record lows was becoming "more balanced."

Minutes from the committee's May meeting show that members again voted unanimously to keep rates and gilt purchases on hold, and that "in the absence of other inflationary pressures, it would be necessary to see more evidence of slack reducing before an increase in bank rate would be warranted."

But they also disclosed that some members feel a move to hike rates appears to be edging closer.

From Capital Economics:

It may not be long before one or two members start to vote to raise interest rates. Nonetheless, most members seem content to leave policy on hold for some time to absorb the slack in the economy.

While the minutes of May's UK MPC meeting strike a slightly less dovish tone than last week's Inflation Report, they still suggest that the first rise in interest rates remains a distant prospect.

From ING:

With the growth story broadening out we are getting closer to a rate rise from the Bank of England.

Our house view remains that the first hike will probably come in February, but given the strength in growth, employment and asset prices the risks are skewed towards a slightly earlier move. If we see wages growth pick up – note the impending 3 per cent rise in national minimum wage and the increase in reported pay awards – then we would be more inclined to bring it forward.

From INS Global Insight:

There are clear indications in the May minutes that some of the more hawkish MPC members are starting to get twitchy.

For the time being, we retain the view that interest rates are most likely to start edging up in the second quarter of 2015, but there is clearly a very real and growing likelihood that the Bank of England will act before then.

The uncertain outlook for when the first interest rate hike will come is heightened by the fact that three members of the MPC are changing by August, with May's meeting being the swansong for Spencer Dale. Paul Fisher and Charlie Bean will also shortly be leaving the MPC.
results.abstract: Here's a quick round-up of reaction to Wednesday's revelation that some members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee believe the decision on whether to lift interest rates off their record lows was becoming "more balanced."

results.title: UK appeals court overturns key fraud case ruling
results.content:
There's been a very significant development in the UK's push to toughen up its prosecution of white collar crime.

The Court of Appeal has overturned a lower court's decision to effectively halt a landmark fraud prosecution, after highly contentious legal aid cuts left the defendants unrepresented by barristers.

In an unusual separate statement released alongside the decision, senior judge Sir Brian Leveson said retaining a "thriving cadre" of barristers willing to take on publicly funded fraud cases and other complex prosecutions was of "fundamental importance" to justice, and urged a resolution between the Ministry of Justice and the profession about how much they should be paid to take on such work.

A 30 per cent reduction by the Ministry of Justice in the rates which the lawyers are paid for complex cases has led to barristers refusing to accept fraud cases at the new lower amount.

There were widespread concerns that a failure to overturn the earlier ruling would have a knock-on effect on other big fraud cases being pursued by the UK's markets watchdog, the Financial Conduct Authority.

That list includes Operation Tabernula, the FCA's biggest insider trading case, and cases involving manipulation of the London interbank offered rate, known as Libor.

From the statement:

This is an application and appeal by the Financial Conduct Authority.

It relates to a stay imposed by His Honour Judge Leonard Q.C. in the Crown Court at Southwark that effectively brought to an end the prosecution of an allegation of conspiracy to defraud and other offences in connection with a land banking scheme.

For the reasons set out in the judgment which has been circulated to the parties in advance and which is available for the press and any interested member of the public, the application is granted and the appeal allowed.

The judge found that there was no realistic prospect of competent advocates with sufficient time to prepare being available in the foreseeable future and that the position was fixed.

We conclude that these findings cannot be sustained and that it was not reasonable for him to reach them. In those circumstances, we order that the proceedings on this indictment be resumed in the Crown Court.
results.abstract: There's been a very significant development in the UK's push to toughen up its prosecution of white collar crime.

results.title: Burberry's Bailey vows to lead in his own way
results.content:
Christopher Bailey took the stage for the first time as chief executive and chief creative officer at Burberry and made it clear that there would be no "fundamental change" to the group's strategy.

"My new role is an unconventional one and my background is not one of a traditional CEO," said Mr Bailey. "I will lead Burberry in my own way."

But Mr Bailey is dedicated to one major tenant of his predecessor Angela Ahrendts' reign: management gobbledygook, reports the FT's Duncan Robinson.

Burberry will have a "heightened emphasis on outwear", which roughly translates as: we will sell more coats.

This will be achieved thanks to "leveraged data and insight". New opportunities abound thanks to "under-penetrated markets". Luckily, Mr Bailey has a strong platform to build on as the luxury group's "dynamic management", which has driven "outperformance".

Mr Bailey has the advantage of taking over a company that is growing faster than its peers. Burberry has also moved into online sales quicker than rivals, who still regard online sales with apprehension, and has been unaffected by the slowdown in China's luxury goods market.

But challenges remain. Burberry has dragged its beauty business in-house in contrast to its rivals who tend to license out their brands to bigger perfume purveyors. Cracking Japan, the world's second largest luxury market, via a relaunch of the brand could also prove treacherous, but has the potential to be extremely lucrative. Burberry took its Chinese business in-house in 2010 to great success.
results.abstract: Christopher Bailey took the stage for the first time as chief executive and chief creative officer at Burberry and made it clear that there would be no "fundamental change" to the group's strategy.

results.title: BoE: decision on interest rates "more balanced"
results.content:
The decision over whether to hike interest rates in the UK off their record lows is becoming "more balanced" for some members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee as the UK's recovery gains momentum, minutes from the committee's May meeting have revealed.

The committee, as expected, voted unanimously to keep the benchmark rate at 0.5 per cent earlier this month.

As some members appear to edge closer to a rate increase, committee members agreed that they would need to see more evidence of slack coming out of Britain's economy before lifting rates, the minutes show.

All agreed that rate rises would only "be a last line of defence" against the building risks posed to financial stability from a rising housing market.

Saumel Tombs, UK economist at Capital Economics, suggested it "may not be long" before one or two members start to vote to rate rises.

Here's the key excerpt:

The Committee's February guidance embodied the expectation that when Bank Rate began to rise, it would do so only gradually and to a level materially below its pre-crisis average.

Although such a path for policy ran a greater risk of a build up in financial imbalances, particularly in the housing market, the Committee noted that the mitigation of such risks was, in the first instance, the responsibility of the FPC: monetary policy should be only a last line of defence.

The case for moving gradually and cautiously was reinforced by uncertainty over the likely impact on the economy of a rise in Bank Rate.

It could be argued that the more gradual the intended rise in Bank Rate, the earlier it might be necessary to start tightening policy. Against that, if productive potential were in part related to the level of demand, then the earlier policy was tightened the greater the risk of incurring a substantial cost in foregone output.

Committee members placed different weights on these considerations and this was reflected in a variety of views on the appropriate path of monetary policy.

The Committee would continue to refine its views as the economy evolved, and for some members the monetary policy decision was becoming more balanced.

In terms of the immediate policy decision, however, all members agreed that, in the absence of other inflationary pressures, it would be necessary to see more evidence of slack reducing before an increase in Bank Rate would be warranted.
results.abstract: The decision over whether to hike interest rates in the UK off their record lows is becoming "more balanced" for some members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee as the UK's recovery gains momentum, minutes from the committee's May meeting have revealed.
